questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You have 10 computers that run Windows 10 and are enrolled in mobile device management (MDM).
You need to deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite to all the computers.
What should you do?

choices.D: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, add an app.
choices.B: From Azure AD, add an app registration.
choices.C: From Azure AD, add an enterprise application.
choices.A: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create a Windows 10 device profile.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It should be D.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/apps-add-office365#select-microsoft-365-apps

Selected Answer: D
Who in the world put A here?

Selected Answer: B
Based on https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/remote-actions/devices-wipe. What is related to the question is the personal data. It says that When you use the Retire device action, the user's personal data is not removed from the device.

Selected Answer: D
To deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite to all the computers enrolled in mobile device management (MDM), you should:

D. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, add an app

Here's a step-by-step guide:

Sign in to the Microsoft Intune admin center.
Navigate to "Apps" > "All apps".
Click on "Add".
Select the app type as "Windows 10" and choose "Microsoft 365 Apps".
Configure the app information and settings as required.
Assign the app to the groups or devices you want to deploy it to.
This method leverages Microsoft Intune to manage and deploy applications to your enrolled devices, ensuring they receive the necessary Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite.

Selected Answer: D
To deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite to all the computers enrolled in mobile device management (MDM), you should add the app from the Microsoft Intune admin center.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

D. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, add an app.

Selected Answer: D
Configuration Profiles deploy config settings not apps.
To deploy the suite you need to add an app. Answer is D.

D. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, add an app.

Navigating to the Microsoft Intune admin center.
Selecting Apps > All apps > Add.
Choosing the appropriate app type (in this case, Microsoft 365 Apps for Windows 10).
Configuring the app deployment settings, such as installation context, deployment intent, and assignment to target devices or user groups.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D
Answer D

Selected Answer: D
To deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite to the 10 Windows 10 computers enrolled in mobile device management (MDM), you should follow these steps: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, add an app. This will allow you to deploy the Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise suite to all the computers efficiently.

Selected Answer: D
Always use intune to upload the app

comments.content:
A. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create a Windows 10 device profile.
- NO, devices are already in MDM.
B. From Azure AD, add an app registration.
- This has nothing to do with the question.
C. From Azure AD, add an enterprise application.
- This has nothing to do with the question.
D. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, add an app.
- This is correct. Since devices are already in MDM, we need to simply create a new app and assing it to all devices.

Selected Answer: A
If the question have ended at "You need to identify noncompliant devices", then B would have been correct. But you need to know which non-compliant device "Accessed OneDrive for Business". That can only be done by A. 

Also there is no such thing as "noncompliant device report" in MS Intune > Reports. Stop copying answers from ChatGPT and use your research and test tenants.

Selected Answer: C
C. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, review the Noncompliant devices report.

By reviewing the Noncompliant devices report in the Intune admin center, you can identify devices that are marked as noncompliant and attempting to access Microsoft OneDrive for Business. This report provides details about device names, users, and specific compliance issues.

A. From the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center, review the Conditional Access Insights and Reporting workbook.

The Conditional Access Insights and Reporting workbook provides comprehensive insights into the usage and effectiveness of conditional access policies. You can use it to review detailed information about device compliance status and access attempts, including any instances where noncompliant devices attempted to access OneDrive for Business. This will help you identify which devices are noncompliant and attempted access to OneDrive for Business, allowing you to take appropriate actions to remediate the compliance issues.
A totally agree

See each device that is not compliant with policy alongside the compliance policy settings these devices are not compliant with.

I think the question is very badly formed. (on purpose, of course)
If you have OD enabled and configured, than yes, any device (including the non-compliants) will try to access it.
If it is not, the non*compliant report will give you only info about which device cannot access, not about did that device try it at all...so no audit info available. So I would vote on "A".

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant.

You have devices enrolled in Microsoft Intune.

You assign a conditional access policy named Policy1 to a group named Group1. Policy1 restricts devices marked as noncompliant from accessing Microsoft OneDrive for Business.

You need to identify which noncompliant devices attempt to access OneDrive for Business.

What should you do?

choices.A: From the Microsoft Entra admin center, review the Conditional Access Insights and Reporting workbook.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, review Device compliance report.
choices.D: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, review the Setting compliance report.
choices.C: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, review the Noncompliant devices report.

-

You use Microsoft Intune to manage Windows 10 devices.

You are designing a reporting solution that will provide reports on the following:

• Compliance policy trends
• Trends in device and user enrollment
• App and operating system version breakdowns of mobile devices

You need to recommend a data source and a data visualization tool for the design.

What should you recommend? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:

It is a trick question because least administrative is Windows Autopilot which would reset the devices. If resetting the device is a concern then it would GPO. Hopefully the exam isn't as vague as this question is

comments.content:
The administrative effor would be extended to perform Windows Autopilot for 2k devices.
The question is only about add the devices to Entra ID and enroll them in intune. A simple GPO to joined them to Entra ID (hybrid join) and automatic enrollment (simple confi) would be less effort then Autopilot. This is my opinion, could be wrong but i would go with the GPO answer.

the GPO policy can hybrid join existing devices to Intune without resetting. That has been the standard practice when you want to go from fully on-prem to Intune managed.

B. a Group Policy object (GPO).

You can create and deploy a Group Policy object (GPO) that configures the devices for hybrid Azure AD join and Intune enrollment. This GPO can include settings such as enabling hybrid Azure AD join and configuring automatic enrollment in Intune. Once applied, the GPO will automatically register all existing computers to Azure AD and enroll them in Intune, ensuring they are properly managed without requiring manual intervention on each device.
B. a Group Policy object (GPO) Correct

discussion.content: ChatGPT: To automatically register all existing computers to Azure AD and enroll them in Intune with minimal administrative effort, you should use **Windows Autopilot deployment profile** (option D). Autopilot allows you to pre-register devices with Azure AD and enroll them in Intune as part of the out-of-box experience for end-users. This helps streamline the deployment process and reduces the need for manual intervention.

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B. a Group Policy object (GPO).

comments.content:
Once the GPO is applied, computers will automatically register with Azure AD and enroll in Intune when users sign in with their Azure AD credentials.

Why the other options are not suitable:

 Autodiscover address record and Autodiscover service connection point (SCP): These are used for discovering Exchange server settings in Outlook clients, not for device registration or enrollment.
 Windows Autopilot deployment profile: This is used for streamlining the setup of new devices, not for managing existing devices.

Here's why:

GPOs are the most efficient way to automate registration and enrollment for existing devices in a hybrid Azure AD environment. They allow you to apply settings to a large number of devices centrally, minimizing the administrative effort involved.

Here's how it works:

 Create a GPO: Use the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to create a new GPO that targets the computers you want to enroll.
 Enable automatic MDM enrollment: Within the GPO, enable the policy setting for "Enable automatic MDM enrollment using default Azure AD credentials."
 Configure MDM user scope: Specify whether the enrollment applies to all users or a specific group of users.
 Apply the GPO: Link the GPO to the appropriate Active Directory organizational unit (OU) to apply it to the targeted computers.

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain. The domain contains 2,000 computers that run Windows 10.

You implement hybrid Azure AD and Microsoft Intune.

You need to automatically register all the existing computers to Azure AD and enroll the computers in Intune. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

What should you use?

discussion.content: Correct. Computer2 got excluded from both rings due to dual group membership.
Due to Microsoft's policy of "exclusion over inclusion" and since Computer 2 is member of both groups, it gets excluded from both policies and hence no policy gets applied to it at all.

I'm not sure this is correct. If a device is assigned to both Group 1 and Group 2, the quality update will be deferred for 10 days. I though this is because when multiple update policies are applied to a single device, the policy with the longest deferral period takes precedence. Can someone point me to documentation that states assigning two groups cancel the policy all together?
Answers are correct.
SEEMS CORRECT

I would say both are "No Effect" as both group are listed in the "Exclude" and as you guys know per Microsoft "Excluded" take precedent over "included or allowed" .. let me know what you think friends

comments.content: Ring1 applies, Ring2 does not. Ring 2 assignments will not interfere with Ring1 assignment. This is how I see it.
